results.title: Metal craft
results.creator_credit: ERPI Classroom Films and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: A craftsman at work making a pewter bowl by spinning and shaping a blank for later soldering to a cast base; and a bronze bowls by raising, smoothing, annealing, planishing, and burnishing a blank disc. Methods of constructing a candlestick mould, inserting the core, pouring, removing, and finishing the pewter cast are demonstrated. The designing, chasing, shaping and soldering of the sides and top of a jewel-box are also demonstrated.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ERPI Classroom Films and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films

results.title: Metadata
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Pierre Moretti and Peter Foldes
results.brief_description: A new direction in the art of film animation-using a computer to assist the animator. In this film, it was the computer of the National Research Council of Canada that performed most of the work of animation, registering the hundreds of movements to produce a fluid, evolving effect. Without the computer, each movement or impression would have had to be painstakingly arranged by hand. The theme of the film is our universal desire to escape the demands of life. A film without words. Music by A. Clavier. (Awards: Oberhausen)
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, Pierre Moretti and Peter Foldes

results.title: Messieurs les Ronds de Cuir = The Pencil Pushers (TV Version)
results.brief_description:
This adaptation of Courteline revolves around a group of public servants working in a Ministry. Boring routine, mental inflexibility, narrowmindness: all the low points of human nature in general, and public administration in particular are being finely observed and satirised.

Credits: Director, writer, Daniel Ceccaldi ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Raymond Pellegrin, Daniel Ceccaldi, Evelyne Buyle, Roger Carel, Raymond Armontel, Bernard Lecoq, Claude Dauphin.

results.title: Messiah of love
results.creator_credit: Don Bosco Multimedia, Vincenzo Labella and Franco Zeffirelli
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Jesus of Nazareth”.
The continuing story of the life of Jesus Christ from: Judas talks to Zerah, the chief of the scribes of the temple; Jesus enters Jerusalem riding a donkey, the crowds are waving palms; the market and the money changers; Jesus is confronted by Zerah and the Pharisees; Judas intervenes and talks to Jesus and Zareh; Jesus addresses the crowds, Nicodemus listens; Barrabas approaches Jesus; Jesus with the childrens in the temple, tells them a parable which he also addresses to the Pharisees.

results.title: Messengers of the Gods
results.brief_description: The story of the crane and its long flight in the imagination of man. Looks at their migration habits, courtship, mating, nesting and feeding rituals. This is a nature documentary of extraordinary quality with eloquent narration.
results.description: The story of the crane and its long flight in the imagination of man. Looks at their migration habits, courtship, mating, nesting and feeding rituals. This is a nature documentary of extraordinary quality with eloquent narration.

results.title: Messengers of peace.- [Rev. ed.]
results.creator_credit: United Nations Television and Al Fox
results.brief_description: This film looks at the philatelic aspects of United Nations’ stamps. The UN has a postal administration and used the mail routes of the world for its won unique international postage stamps. Some of the world’s leading artists prepare the designs which appear on the stamps.
results.description: This film looks at the philatelic aspects of United Nations’ stamps. The UN has a postal administration and used the mail routes of the world for its won unique international postage stamps. Some of the world’s leading artists prepare the designs which appear on the stamps.

results.title: Messages: Yellow ball workshop
results.brief_description: A series of advice films for children. Three on diet; good food for energy, beauty and to prevent overweight. One on the dangers of listening to clever advertising and one on the possible embarrassment of not reading the label correctly.

results.title: Message from Moree (A) [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Rymer Bayly Watson, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Bevan Childs and Judy Rymer
results.brief_description: Moree, several hours north-west of Sydney, once had the reputation for being New South Wales’ most racist town, particularly during the 1990s. A rich agricultural district of wealthy farmers, Moree also is home to a poverty-stricken mainly unemployed minority Aboriginal community, giving rise to a high crime rate, violence, racism, despair and social disintegration. By 1996 Moree was in crisis with unemployment for Aboriginals at 44% (non-Aboriginals 7%). Dick Estens, a cotton farmer whose passion for the underdog and a refusal to acknowledge or accept failure, set about with a private group of concerned citizens in establishing the AES (Aboriginal Employment Strategy). His mission was to gain employment for Aboriginal people through a process of mentoring and partnerships. This documentary follows the handover by Dick Estens of the leadership of the AES to the Aboriginal community and the appointment of Cathy Duncan, a young tenacious Aboriginal educator, as Chair of the AES. Together Cathy and Dick begin to inspire change in the town of Moree, bringing a new hope of reconciliation between blacks and whites, increased employment for Aboriginals and a more positive attitude and respect between the two cultures. The partnership between Dick and Cathy is an interesting one with suspicion slowly turning into trust, ignorance into understanding, despair into hope and eventually, through compromise, mutual respect and admiration for each other as they strive towards a common goal. An extraordinary story of a small community committed to change. Contains archival footage, some scenes in b&w. For more information see “www.abc.net.au/message/tv/docos/moree/”

results.title: Message from a dinosaur
results.brief_description: Explains how the past is reconstructed from fossil remains, how palaeontologists hypothesise about prehistoric life forms, and how new forms of life evolved from the environmental changes. Organisms which cannot adapt to changing conditions do not survive.
results.description: Explains how the past is reconstructed from fossil remains, how palaeontologists hypothesise about prehistoric life forms, and how new forms of life evolved from the environmental changes. Organisms which cannot adapt to changing conditions do not survive.
